entry.et: Middle English, from Anglo-French or Latin; Anglo-French estendre, from Latin extendere, from ex- + tendere to stretch thin

def.dt: :to spread or stretch forth :unbend extended both her arms
:to cause (as a horse) to move at full stride
:to exert (oneself) to full capacity could work long and hard without seeming to extend himself
:to increase the bulk of (as by adding a cheaper substance or a modifier)
def.set: Middle English, from Medieval Latin extendere (from Latin) or Anglo-French estendre, from Old French
def.dt: :to take possession of (as lands) by a writ of extent
:to make the offer of :proffer extending aid to the needy extending their greetings
:to make available extending credit to customers
:to cause to reach (as in distance or scope) national authority was extended over new territories
:to cause to be longer :prolong extend the side of a triangle extended their visit another day
:to prolong the time of payment of
:advance further extending her potential through job training
:to cause to be of greater area or volume :enlarge extended the patio to the back of the house
:to increase the scope, meaning, or application of :broaden beauty, I suppose, opens the heart, extends the consciousness Algernon Blackwood
:to stretch out in distance, space, or time :reach their jurisdiction extended over the whole area
:to reach in scope or application his concern extends beyond mere business to real service to his customers

entry.pt: extend lengthen prolong protract mean to draw out or add to so as to increase in length. extend and lengthen imply a drawing out in space or time but extend may also imply increase in width, scope, area, or range extend a vacation extend welfare services lengthen a skirt lengthen the workweek. prolong suggests chiefly increase in duration especially beyond usual limits prolonged illness. protract adds to prolong implications of needlessness, vexation, or indefiniteness protracted litigation.
